Description: Hollow terracotta figure of Bes, naked, with a high feathered headdress, standing on a small plinth with a moulding at the top. He is armed, his sword held high, and holds a round shield on his left arm. Back plain, with circular vent. Two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt, with some white inclusions. Dull red slip on front.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: H. Rowland. Ptolemaic, probably second to first century BC. Comparanda. Near: Dunand 1990: no. 39, dated Roman period; Geßler-Löhr et al. 1978: no. 412, said to be from the Fayum; Paul 1959: no. 307; Petrie Museum uc47974, and the plaster mould uc33302, both from Memphis; Skupinska-Løvset 1978: no. UT 111, dated first century AD; Török 1995: no. 17. Near, but wearing armour: Fischer 1994: no. 544, dated late Hellenistic = Vogt 1924: pl. xxiii:2.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3096)
